newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Swiss 1996 federal deficit larger than planned.
newsitem.headline: Swiss 1996 federal deficit larger than planned.

text.p: Switzerland's 1996 federal deficit was 315 million Swiss francs over budget at 4.36 billion francs due to lower than expected tax and customs income, the Finance Ministry said on Wednesday.
"The federal debt grew by five billion to 87 billion Swiss francs," a ministry statement said, adding that interest payments were eight million Swiss francs a day.
It said the budget remained overloaded with structural committments to spending.
Revenues were 1.1 percent or 447 million Swiss francs under budget, which was only partially offset by using left-over funds from earlier years to lower 1996 spending by 132 million.
"Reforming federal finances remains a pressing task of the coming years," it added.
Switzerland's parliament in December approved a federal budget for 1997 with a deficit of 5.77 billion Swiss francs, as against a 3.26 billion shortfall in 1995.
The biggest factor in 1996 budget growth was higher social security costs, which rose 24.7 percent from 1995 to total 12.7 billion francs out of total expenditures of 43.8 billion.

Social security spending was driven by higher unemployment payments, pension contributions and health insurance contributions due to a stagnent economy, higher joblessness, an aging population and health reform.
Agricultural spending also rose, growing 11.5 percent to 3.9 billion as the mad cow disease scare undermined efforts to cut subsidies by prompting support payments for cattle and beef producers.
On the other side, revenues failed to meet expectations as a sixth year of economic stagnation dampened sales, slowed imports and lower income taxes.
Revenues totalled 39.5 billion Swiss francs last year after 37.3 billion the year before.

The Swiss federal budget has less of a market impact than those in other industrialised countries because of the relatively large volume of spending by the 26 cantons (states) and half-cantons and hundreds of community authorities. -- Zurich Newsroom, +41-1-631 7340
